characters: EXT. ST JOHN'S, SMITH SQUARE. NIGHT
EXT. ST JOHN'S SMITH SQUARE. NIGHT
INT/EXT. CAR NEW COUNTRY ROAD. DAY
INT. ST JOHN'S SMITH SQUARE. NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nice girls' school in a south west London suburb. We se girls doing what girls did in a nice girls' school in 196 walking with books on their heads, practising their handwriting, making cakes, playing lacrosse, dancing with each other.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: In one of the classrooms, MISS STUBBS, an attractive, bright, animated schoolteacher, is talking to a small gro of sixteen-year-old girls. Some of these girls seem to be daydreaming - looking out of the window, examining their fingernails. A couple, including a bespectacled girl who looks five years younger than everyone else in the class, write down everything the teacher says. Only one, JENNY, beautiful and animated, seems to be listening in the spir in which Miss Stubbs would like her to listen. She's smiling, eyes shining - she loves Miss Stubbs, and these lessons. Miss Stubbs asks a question, and Jenny puts up h hand - the only one in the class to do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock-sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny. Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it because Mr Rochester's                           blind?

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny's bedroom. Books about ponies, a much loved teddy bear; a cello huge in the small room leans against the wall. Jenny is bent over a small desk. Victorian novels, Latin primers and dictionaries teeter in huge towers either sid of her. She stands and stretches as she turns to us. She kneels and flicks through her half-dozen or so LPs on the floor near a cheap record player - they're all classical, mostly by Elgar, apart from a Juliette Greco record. This is the one she chooses. As the music begins, she sings along. Immediately there is a thumping noise - someone underneat her is banging on the ceiling impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear any French singing. French singing wasn't on the syllabus, last time I looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny sighs, and reaches for the volume control. She turn the music down so low that she has to lie down and put he head right next to the Dansette to hear it. Close on Jenny as she silently mouths the words along wit the almost inaudible track.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny, her mother and father are finishing Sunday lunch. Jenny's father JACK is in his forties, MARJORIE, her moth is slightly younger than Jack, but every bit as middle- aged. The food is grey and brown, in keeping with the colour scheme of the house. They aren't talking - they're listening to Mantovani on the radio. Jenny gets up from t lunch table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got an English essay to do by tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear anything through the ceiling this afternoon, apart from the sound of sweat dripping onto textbooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we agreed that cello was my interest or hobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's already your interest or hobby. When they ask you "What's your interest or hobby?" at your Oxford interview, you can say, "Cello". That wouldn't be a lie. You don't need to practise a hobby. A hobby is a hobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to be good at it. You just have to be interested in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I stop going to the youth orchestra, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The orchestra shows you're a joiner-inner. Universities like joiner-inners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Yes. But. I've already joined in. So now I can stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you stop, that shows the opposite, doesn't it? That shows you're a rebel. They don't want that at Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They don't want people who think for themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (missing the sarcasm, as is his wont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course they don't.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SCHOOL HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny with cello sits in the string section. Everyone is getting settled, tuning up, latecomers still arriving. Along the row from Jenny, tuning his violin, is a nice- looking boy of her age, GRAHAM, and she waves at him. Two 13 year old boys sitting between them wave too, parodically, and then blow kisses, much to Graham's embarrassment and Jenny's fury. The silly boys dissolve in fits of giggles: this is clear one of the funniest moments of their lives - until one of them farts noisily and, it would appear from all the frantic gesturing, pungently. The comic value of the fart tops even the comic value of the wave, and they are scarcely able to stay seated, such is their mirth.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny and Graham are talking while he struggles to take h bike out of a bicycle rack slightly unbalanced by the violin strapped to his back. Graham is nervous, chronically unconfident and shy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I wear, you know, Sunday best?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better, I'm afraid. Just to show my father you're un jeune homme serieux, not a teddy boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be all right. I won't wait.                         It's going to bucket down in a                            minute. I'll see you at the                               weekend.                                                  Jenny moves as quickly as she can towards the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Bye. The two silly boys from before arrive to blow more kisses

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, darling! See you at the                          weekend! I will miss you with all                         of my heart! Graham blushes. Jenny swipes the chief offender over the head with her sheet music.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BUS STOP. DAY
dialogues.text: The rain has begun. Jenny attempts to cover herself. A mother and two children cross the road in front of her, a a beautiful, sleek red sports car - a Bristol - stops to let them across. David, possibly in his mid-thirties, dapper, and almost but not quite handsome, is driving the car. David, distracted, impatient, spots Jenny at the bus stop. In front of the car a small wellington boot drops off the foot of one of the children,further slowing down their painfully slow progress across the road. Jenny is wet. David makes eye contact. Jenny smiles ruefully, and enchantingly. David sighs, and then hesitat for a moment. The window of the Bristol slowly rolls down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Jenny ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. If you've got any sense, you wouldn't take a lift from a strange man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny smiles thinly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, however, a music lover, and I'm worried about your cello. So                          what I propose is, you put it in                          the car and walk alongside me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know you won't just drive off with the cello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Good point. He winds down the other window and waves on the cars that have stopped behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much does a new cello cost? Twenty pounds? Thirty? I don't know. Let's say thirty. He pulls out a wallet, takes out three ten-pound notes, hands them to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. Security. Jenny laughs and waves the money away. 7   EXT. STREET. NEAR SCHOOL. DAY. Later. The cello is in the back seat of the Bristol. Jenn is trotting alongside the car, while David leans nonchalantly across the passenger seat to talk to her whi driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm David, by the way. She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you are...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny. (Beat) I've never seen a car like this before. C'est tres chic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a Bristol. Not many of `em made. Jenny nods, but doesn't know how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did the concert go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a rehearsal. The concert's next Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you playing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making a face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elgar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Elgar. I often think it's a shame he spent so much time in Worcester, don't you? Worcester's too near Birmingham. And you can hear that in the music. There's a horrible Brummy accent in there, if you listen hard enough. Jenny looks at him and smiles. She hadn't expected him to be able to make Elgar jokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I'm not sure Elgar and                          Jews mix very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a Jew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I am. I wasn't...accusing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (She smiles awkwardly.) Can I sit in the car with my cello? David stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jump in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny shuts the door and sinks approvingly into the white leather seat. David regards the dripping girl with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's even nicer on the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to, madam? Jenny makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only live round the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a shame. We'll just make it last as long as we can.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. NEAR JENNY'S. DAY
dialogues.text: The Bristol is crawling along the road at walking pace.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR JENNY'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: David reaches across Jenny while driving slowly, opens th glove compartment and takes out a packet of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better not. I'm a bit close to home. David lights one for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose cellists must go to a lot of concerts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't go to any concerts. We                           don't believe in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they're real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So people say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we believe in them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose...What would he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father, this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Darkly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. He'd say there's no point to them. They're just for fun. Apart from school concerts, of course, which are no fun at all, so we go to those. The proper ones don't help you get                          on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which of course is what is so                           wonderful about them. Anyway, you'll go one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartfelt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I will. I know. Sometimes it seems as though that's what all this slog is for. If I get to University, I'm going to read what I want and think about what I want and listen to what I want. And I'm going to look at paintings and go to French films and talk to people who know lots about lots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you. Which University?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford. If I'm lucky. Did you go anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I studied at what I believe they call the University of Life. And I didn't get a very good degree there. Jenny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is me. Thank you. She gets out of the car with the cello. David stares afte her for a moment, then drives off.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S SITTING-ROOM. AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Jenny, her parents and Graham are eating afternoon tea - neat fish-paste sandwiches, Battenberg cake, best china.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your mother, Graham?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fine, thanks. She sends her best, by the way. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you applying, Graham? Jenny looks embarrassed. She knows what's coming. GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure yet. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when will you be sure? You can't let the grass grow under your feet, you know. Otherwise you'll be at the back of the queue. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan) I suppose so. I suppose the growing grass would knock you off balance, and then you'd fall over, and by the time you picked yourself up, there'd be a queue. Her father shoots her a look - is she being cheeky? GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might take a year off. Jenny winces. Jack looks at him as if he's just said he'l take all his clothes off. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) I don't know. Maybe do some travelling, that sort of thing. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travelling? What are you, a teddy boy? Close-up of Jenny - she knows what's coming, and can't be it. Beat. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding at Jenny) You know she's going to Oxford, don't you? Oxford. English. If we can get her Latin up to scratch. Jenny sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she's studying English at Oxford while you're a wandering Jew... Jenny looks at him curiously. Graham steels himself to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Mellor...I'm not a teddy boy. I'm an homme serieux. Jeune. An homme jeune serieux homme. Jenny winces again. Her father stares at Graham. Graham blushes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. EVENING
dialogues.text: It's the night of the youth orchestra concert. Jenny, her mother and father are on their way out of the door. Jack carrying the cello. Jenny is in her school uniform, with her hair scrubbed back in a severe ponytail. The three of them are flustered. Jenny opens the front door for her father and he stumbles outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: 12A INT/EXT. JENNY'S HOUSE. EVENING
dialogues.text: She has seen something on the doorstep, and she stoops to pick it up - a large bunch of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're for me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are they from? Jenny opens the card that's attached to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh. Him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's `him'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just...A chap I met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chap who sends flowers? So he's a man-chap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he is, really. Jack stares at the flowers in disbelief. The bunch of flowers has created in Jack the kind of panic and fear mo typically associated with a biochemical attack. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on here? MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily, knowing the trouble this will cause) Jack,I'm afraid Jenny has been sent some flowers by a chap. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chap? What kind of chap? Who? Why? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently) He's wishing me luck for tonight. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure that's all he's wishing? And where does he get the money from? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He earns it, I expect. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, he earns it? Why isn't he at school? What does he do? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we just go? Otherwise the bunch of good-luck flowers will actually be responsible for me actually missing the concert. Which would be ironic, n'est ce pas? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't like it. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection noted. Jenny? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten bob's worth of luck, I reckon. That's a lot for a schoolgirl. You can't leave them out here, anyway. I'd burgle a house that had flowers outside. They'll think we're made of money.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. EVENING
dialogues.text: Jenny sighs, puts them inside the house, shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COFFEE BAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny and two school friends, HATTIE and TINA, are sittin at a table in a typical late-50s coffee bar, sipping cappuccinos. Jenny is easily the most attractive of the three - and also, we will see, possibly the cleverest. HATTIE is slower than the other two, and a lot frumpier; TINA is pretty, and sharp rather than clever. She is also the least middle-class of the three - she's clearly a scholarship girl. They are all dressed in an unflattering and unambiguous school uniform - no attempts to disguise with more fashionable accessories. Jenny is smoking pretentiously, and seems to be practising some kind of pout. Tina starts to slurp the froth from her cappuccino with a spoon, inelegantly and noisily. Jenny tuts her disapproval. Tina sighs, and puts her spoon down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole point about him is that                        he doesn't feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still don't have to like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camus doesn't want you to like him. What he's trying to say is that feeling is bourgeois. Being engagee is bourgeois. His mother dies and he doesn't feel anything. He kills this Arab and he doesn't feel anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't feel anything if my mother died. Does that make me an existentialist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That just makes you a cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Une vache. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET/COFFEE BAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny, Hattie and Tina emerge from the cafe, talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm going to be French. I'm going to Paris and I'm going to smoke and listen to Jacques Brel and wear black. And I won't speak. Ever. C'est plus chic, comme... She breaks off. Parked outside a tobacconists on the othe side of the road is the red Bristol. She looks towards th shop, and David emerges with a copy of the Times and a packet of cigars. Jenny crosses the road to talk to him while the others watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fine. I think. I mean, I didn't mess my bit up, anyway. And no-one got thrown out of the orchestra afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always the mark of a cultural triumph. Listen. I'm glad I ran into you. What are you doing on Friday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes. Of course. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm going to listen to                        some Schubert in St John's, Smith                     Square. My friends Danny and                          Helen will be going too, so it wouldn't be...I'll tell you what. I'll come and pick you up, and if your mother and father disapprove, then you can have the tickets and go with one of them. How does that sound? Jenny doesn't know what to say. She looks at David, and h eagerness to please seems to convince her. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. And I'd like you to take me. I'd like to go with someone who knows when to clap. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I usually watch Danny. He knows that sort of thing. Jenny smiles. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven? And we'll probably go for a spot of supper afterwards, if you...But if you, if that's not...Well, we can always put you in a taxi. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flat disbelief) Supper. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trouble is, we'll already have eaten. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. I mean, if you'd like supper, then, perhaps on Friday you could...not eat? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed again) Oh. Yes. Of course. Jenny smiles, and rejoins her friends on the other side o the road. Tina and Hattie are standing there almost with their mouths open, amazed. She doesn't say anything and starts to walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I just had the strangest dream. I dreamed you crossed the road and spoke to a handsome man with the most beautiful car I've ever seen. And then you came back and you didn't mention it. Jenny smiles enigmatically. Tina grabs Jenny mock-urgentl TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Oo wazzee? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (light, playful) Just a man who's been trying to pick me up. We're going to a concert on Friday night. And then we're having a spot of supper. TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrieking) A spot of supper?                                     JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've heard of supper? HATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've heard of it. But we've never eaten it.                                       JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither of you is interested in the concert part, I notice. HATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Of course not. TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! I've only just realised! That's what's going to happen to you, isn't it? Look at her! Men are going to pick her up in the street and take her out to supper! HATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you're right, Tina. I hadn't thought of that. Look at her. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so daft. TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to attract the attention of boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she's fighting off men. Anyway. You're going to have to tell us more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because no man's ever   going to ask us out to supper.   Not until we're ladies, anyway.   You're going to have to tell   us everything. Otherwise   it's not fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There won't be anything to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, make something up, then.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. EVENING
dialogues.text: Jenny is dressed up for her evening out. She looks good, but also stiff, uncomfortable - she's not herself in her dress, which looks too old for her. Her father is standin in front of her, shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't allow it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. He's quite happy for you to take me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertainly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John's Smith Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm sure we could find out. Marjorie comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in Westminster. Just around                     the corner from the Abbey.                           Jack looks at her as if she'd just given directions to th nearest opium den. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How d'you know that? MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a life before we were married, you know. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He soon put a stop to that. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There we are. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near Westminster Abbey. I'm not                      going all the way over there. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trouble is, that's where St                      John's Smith Square is.                              JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I've just said. That's where I'm not going. There must be something on locally. Where's the paper? MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, she wants to see someone who can play. She doesn't want to see Sheila Kirkland scratching away. I'll take her. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how are you going to get over                    there? RAF helicopter?                               The doorbell rings. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him. Now what? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, bloody hell. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny starts towards the door, and then turns. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and by the way...David's a Jew. A wandering Jew. So watch yourself. She   goes to the door. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panic-stricken and shouting) What's she talking about? I've never said anything like that in my life! Anyway, it's just an expression! I'm not against the Jews! Jenny comes back in with David, who is dressed stylishly his early-60s young executive leisurewear - sports jacket slacks, cashmere sweater. He looks out of place - he is brighter and brasher than his surroundings, the most colourful thing in the room, and he seems intimidatingly exotic. David has obviously heard Jack's last line. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) I'm glad to hear it. Hello. David                    Goldman.                                             He offers his hand. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean I'm not against you... Actually, I did mean that, because I'm not, but... JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! David's hand is still extended - in his confusion and embarrassment, Jack hasn't yet taken it. He does so now, and shakes it for way too long. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. What I'm saying is that you're not the sort of, of person I'd be against, if I were the sort of person who was against...people. You're not an old...Oh, dear. I'm Jack, and this is Marjorie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan) You didn't tell me you had a sister, Jenny. General confusion, until David chuckles naughtily. Marjor giggles, and then offers her hand. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lucky man, Jack. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I am, yes. They all sit down. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Gosh. (He looks around approvingly.) This is lovely. Marjorie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, David. Can I get you a drink? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love one, Jack, but we're running a little late. If Jenny's ready, perhaps we'll shoot off. Jenny looks at her father, and takes a calculated gamble. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Well. Dad's got something to tell you. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, nothing...It was more of a question, really. How would you get to St John's Smith Square                         from here? For future reference? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's a pretty straight run, really. Up to Hammersmith, take                       the A4 through Kensington and                         you're there.                                         JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple as that. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple as that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack smiles broadly. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playfully) So shall I book some tickets for                      something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still smiling) No. Beat. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back by ten, please, David. She's usually in bed by then. Jenny winces. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping Jenny would come with me afterwards to have a bite of supper with my aunt Helen. Jenny studies him carefully. Suddenly his friends Danny a Helen have become `Aunt Helen'. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I suppose... DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about if I promise to have her in by eleven thirty? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's Friday night. And if you're going out to the West End... DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jack. I appreciate it. See you again. They exchange warm handshakes. He turns to Marjorie. Marjorie extends her hand. David takes it, but kisses it suavely,leaving her a little flustered. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye. Jenny and David leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffing the air)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that smell? Has he got perfume on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called after-shave, Jack. And it makes a change from carbolic soap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least there's no confusion, if you smell of carbolic soap. Marjorie rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's ever going to get confused about you, dear.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ST JOHN'S, SMITH SQUARE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny and David walk toward the beautiful hall. Jenny suddenly looks young in the dress that looks too old for her - other adults are milling around outside, and the women don't look like girls dressed up. David makes for a incredibly glamorous and attractive couple in their late twenties who are waiting outside - DANNY and HELEN. Helen is as far from anyone's idea of an aunt as one can get. She's no more beautiful than Jenny, but she's dressed bot appropriately and spectacularly, in early-60s, pre-hippy Bohemian gear. She turns heads in a way that Jenny is not yet able to. Danny too is attractive, but soberly so. Dav and Jenny are, in a way, paler, less striking versions of these two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello hello. Are we late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping we'd miss the                               beginning, and then it wouldn't                          be worth going in, and we could                          go off dancing or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen is one of the more                                 reluctant members of tonight's                           audience.                                                Jenny and David laugh politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny, these are my friends Helen                        and Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny shakes hands with the two of them. They both give h fascinated and clearly appraising looks. They have heard about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we?                                               They walk into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ST JOHN'S SMITH SQUARE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful hall - Jenny is dazzled by the surroundings and the company. She's particularly bowled over by Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. We can leave our coats                            over there. I want to get rid of                        this. She nods at the coat she's carrying. Jenny looks thrilled at the prospect of spending a couple of minutes with Hele Danny hands Helen his coat, without saying anything. The girls walk over to another reception table a few yards away, behind which is a cloakroom. A lady is exchanging overcoats for tickets. Almost involuntarily, Jenny touche the sleeve of Helen's velvety jacket. She stops herself. Helen notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK. It's nice, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful. Where did it come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, South Ken somewhere. Helen looks at Jenny's outfit, her frumpy `smart' dress, apparently wanting to return the compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding at the dress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is...Well, it's good for this sort of concert, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen is now at the front of the queue, and hands her coa over imperiously. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should go shopping together one day, if you want. She takes a ticket from the cloakroom lady. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be nice. But South Ken... C'est beaucoup trop cher pour moi. They stare at each other. Helen is bewildered, Jenny embarrassed. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just said....It was too expensive for me. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you didn't. You said something completely different. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just...Well, I said it in French. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In French? Why? Jenny feels humiliated; she is yet to realise what we can see - that Helen is simply very dim. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Jenny looks away. Helen stares at her. The performance be rings, and they make their way back to the men. To Jenny' surprise and pleasure, Helen links arms with her as they walk. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway. It's too expensive for me, too. We don't have to worry about that. If you want something in South Ken, get David to take you shopping. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why on earth would he want to take me shopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen makes a knowing face.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ST JOHN'S SMITH SQUARE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: David, Jenny, Danny and Helen in a row in the middle of t auditorium, watching the stage and listening to the music Jenny can't concentrate - she's too excited by the occasi and the company. Jenny sneaks a glance at Helen, who star straight ahead, unblinking and enigmatic. David is smilin as if he's trying to communicate enjoyment; Danny's eyes flicker across the stage - he understands the music, its component parts, which musicians are contributing what. Jenny takes it all in.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ST JOHN'S SMITH SQUARE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny, David, Danny and Helen emerge with the other conce goers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I booked a table at Juliette's.                           Will that kill the mood, do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I do hope so.                                         The others laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always think I'm going to my own funeral when I listen to classical music. (Tentatively) That was classical, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Very classical. As classical as you can get. Helen looks pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette's it is, then. Heaven forbid that we should end the evening reflecting on our own mortality. Jenny smiles in delight. She's never met people like this

dialogues.speaker: INT. JULIETTE'S. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A singer in the Julie London mould is singing `I'm In The Mood For Love' while cigarette girls and glamorous waitresses patrol the tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny is sitting with the others at a table in the club, eating and talking. She looks about twelve, but she's thrilled to be there. We know now that her life can never be the same again, and there will be no going back to fis paste sandwiches with spotty Graham. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you never heard "Chante Francoise Sagan"? Jenny shakes her head. Her eyes are wide - she's clearly awe-struck. David offers her a cigarette - a Gitane - whi she takes. He lights it for her while she's listening. DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's wonderful. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've only got....Well, I think it's just called `Juliette Greco'. The one with the eyes on the sleeve. I saved up and got my French conversation teacher to bring it back after Christmas. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a French conversation teacher? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you suddenly speak French for no reason? DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring her) You must have seen her sing?                          Jenny shakes her head again and smiles. Where would she have seen Juliette Greco? Danny, meanwhile, is baffled. W hasn't seen Juliette Greco? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's marvellous. DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you should see her in Paris, not here. David will take you. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to. You'd fit right in. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) Better than here, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wonderful to find a young person who wants to know things. There's so much I want you to see. They sip their drinks pensively, possibly to allow time f the double-entendre to disappear into the smoke. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still all right to come and have a look at that Pembroke Villas place with me on Friday, Danny? DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. No. Can't do it. There's a Burne-Jones coming up at Christie's on Friday. And I want                      it.                                                   JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing in disbelief) You're thinking of buying a Burne- Jones? A real one? DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have a feeling that the pre-Raphaelites are going to take off. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the pre-Raphaelites. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited by her education) Do you? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Rossetti and Burne-Jones, anyway. Not Holman Hunt, so much. He's so garish. Danny looks at her. There's clearly more to this schoolgi than he thought. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely! Why don't we all go to the auction? Wouldn't that be fun? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An auction. Gosh. How exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next Friday morning. David will pick you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crestfallen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're busy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Yes. She doesn't want to explain why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tant pis.                                                Helen looks at him aghast. Why has he started speaking French?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're busy? Jenny hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm sure I could....re- arrange. That would be lovely.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny lets herself quietly into the house. The hallway is dark, but she can hear noises from the kitchen. She pokes her head round the corner, and sees her mother doing the washing-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, love. Did you have a nice time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get this casserole dish clean. We had hot-pot tonight, and it's all burnt round...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's twenty-five to twelve. We finish tea at seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what the time is. How was your evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was...It was the best night of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he took you home in his car? Right to the door? Jenny looks at her. She doesn't seem to have heard what Jenny has just said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Mum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm glad you enjoyed the concert.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny, Hattie and Tina are    sitting on their desks, wai for the start of a lesson.    Nine or ten classmates are scattered around the room,    talking distractedly, but Jenny's group is much more    animated: Tina and Hattie a leaning forward, listening    to Jenny, their eyes bright They are clearly awestruck    by Jenny's tales of the out world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hattie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in Schubert. I want to know what else was on the programme. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was nothing like that. He was the perfect gentleman. He just said he wanted to take me places and show me things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things plural? Oh my Gawd! More laughter. The English teacher, MISS STUBBS, young an fresh-faced and lively-looking, enters, and picks up on the excitement of Jenny's coterie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew that in the end `Jane Eyre' would work its magic upon you. I'm presuming that's what you're so animated about. The students start to sit down at desks in a more conventional arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Jane Eyre' and Jenny's new boyfriend. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not my "new boyfriend". God. TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. He's more a man- friend, isn't he? He's got a sports-car, Miss Stubbs. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. A Mr Rochester figure. TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he must be as blind as Mr Rochester. Laughter. Jenny pulls a face at her. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there no end to your thirst for literary understanding, Jenny? As you may have noticed, I'm attempting to turn the subject away from Jenny's lurid love-life and towards the matter in hand. She starts to hand out essays. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's quite clear on this evidence that most of you know much too much about the former, and almost nothing about the latter. Reluctantly I must concede that Jenny is evidently an expert on both matters. Excellent as always, Jenny. Miss Stubbs slaps an essay down on Jenny's desk. We can s that it's marked `A+'.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny at her desk, working. She puts down her pen, distracted.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DAVID'S CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: David sitting in his Bristol, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: We see the Bristol parked outside, and Jenny walking towards it, a small figure in a large playground. She's clearly just changed out of her school uniform, and she's making last-minute adjustments to her civvies. A teacher walks towards her, and Jenny almost freezes - but the teacher merely smiles pleasantly and walks past. Jenny keeps walking at a measured pace for a moment and then breaks into a run.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR/DILAPIDATED HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny and David are driving along a North Kensington street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know Danny? David is distracted. He's driving slowly, apparently looking for an address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know. We kept bumping into each other, and we became pals, and we've ended up doing a bit of work together, when it suits us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Property. A bit of art dealing. Some buying and selling. This and that... He stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be two seconds. He gets out of the car, and Jenny watches him as he cross the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside a dilapidated house covered in scaffolding stands large West Indian family, mother, father, three or four small children and a dog. They are surrounded by what appears to be all their worldly goods. David squats down his haunches, talks to the kids, tousles the hair of the smallest. Then he takes out a bunch of keys and ushers th family down the path. He unlocks the door and leads them inside. In an upper window of the house, we see an old lady peeri down anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET/DILAPIDATED HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: David emerges from the house, jangling his keys.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny opens the glove compartment where David keeps his cigarettes, takes out the packet, removes one for herself offers the packet to David as he gets into the car. He lights them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know those, those ...Negro people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're clients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clients?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny darling, even schwarzers have to live somewhere. And it's not as if they can rent off their own kind, is it? He starts the car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I quite understand what you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to. It's too boring. All you need to know is that I work in property so that I can take you to nice places. Jenny's POV of the black family in one window, and the little old lady disappearing from another.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHRISTIE'S. DAY
dialogues.text: Danny intent on a catalogue, Helen gazing dreamily into space, as David and Jenny push their way through the crowded auction room. The auctioneer burbles on in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You nearly missed it. Jenny is in awe of rich London in all its finery. The auctioneer clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We turn to lot 41, The Tree of Forgiveness, by Sir Edward Burne- Jones. This is a rare opportunity to purchase a key work of the Pre- Raphaelite movement. Who will start me off at five hundred guineas? Jenny glances at Danny. He makes no move at this price. Neither does anyone else. He's poised and listening hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred? A middle-aged lady, the epitome of the middle-aged contemporary Sloane, twin-set, pearls and a lot of      f powder, raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, madam. Three hundred? A man raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I hear three-fifty? The middle -aged Sloane nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over to you sir. Four hundred guineas? Thank you. Four hundred and fifty... Danny continues to sit there. Jenny is confused. The midd aged lady bids four-fifty. David, sitting next to Danny, whispers something to him. Danny nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Jenny)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn. Jenny looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AUCTIONEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No further bids? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick! Jenny raises her hand high, just as she'd do at school. AUCTIONEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred guineas from the                        very eager new bidder.                               People look round and smile when they see who has come in Jenny blushes, but stares fixedly ahead. AUCTIONEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred and fifty, madam?                       Thank you.                                           Jenny looks at David, who nods. AUCTIONEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six hundred guineas.                                 Jenny gestures more economically. AUCTIONEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six-fifty? Thank you, madam.                         Seven hundred...                                     Jenny is almost insouciant this time. AUCTIONEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven hundred?                                       The middle-aged lady shakes her head and purses her lips. when asked if she wants to bid 700. AUCTIONEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sold for six hundred and fifty                       guineas. Thank you.                                  He brings down the gavel, and a murmur goes around the room. Jenny is excited and giggly. David pats her on the back. AUCTIONEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name, please?                                   Jenny looks at Danny. DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who you are.                                JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Danny)                                       Jenny Mellor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who you are, too. Tell                            him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder,to auctioneer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny Mellor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Couldn't have bought                          it without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done. A nerveless performance. Jenny beams. She's thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DANNY'S FLAT. DAY
dialogues.text: A beautiful, large, airy sitting room in the first-floor flat in Bedford Square. The flat is unusually and tastefully decorated, opulent and indicative of Bohemian good taste. Jenny is sipping a glass of white wine and walking around the room enthralled, looking at Danny's existing Pre-Raphaelite art collection; he has three or four big paintings proudly displayed on his walls. Danny is talking her through them while Helen and David, sittin on the sofa, watch - David proudly, Helen impassively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of years ago you could pick these up for fifty quid, you know. Nobody was interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Fifty pounds? I don't believe you. Suddenly Jenny sees a cello in the corner of the room - a good one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a Lockey-Hill!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There aren't many people who come in here and say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful. Do you play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to. I vowed to myself that one day I'd own one of these. And now I own one and never touch it. It's vulgar to put it on show, really. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to Jenny. DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be even more vulgar. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play for us, Jenny. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh, no. One day. When I'm good enough for it. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's good enough now. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, David. You've never heard me. Danny stands up and stretches. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall come to hear you in St              John's Smith Square. Or in                  Oxford, when you get there. DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should all go and spend a weekend in Oxford. Straw boaters, punting, cream teas, antiquarian bookshops. Bit of business, if we can find it. What about next weekend? DAVID/HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weekend away? I wouldn't be allowed to do that. They all look at her. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find a way. I'll talk to them. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Marjorie. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford. Jenny   hoots with derision. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to ask my father if I can go away with you for the weekend? He'd have you arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet you you can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much? DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Be careful, Jenny. You don't know who you're dealing with. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half-a-crown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on. They shake hands. Jenny suddenly notice the clock on Danny's mantelpiece. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mon dieu! You must take me back to school. And I've got to change back into my uniform. There is a silence. Danny and David make momentary eye contact - they are clearly contemplating the erotic possibilities of Jenny's last sentence. Helen notices. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, behave yourselves. Jenny looks at them all, mystified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny is in her Latin class, waiting for the lesson to begin. Tina and Hattie aren't with her, and she sits on h own -the atmosphere of the class is very different from Miss Stubbs' English lessons. The girls are different, mo serious, less fun, and the atmosphere is more sombre. The teacher, MRS WILSON, is older, plainer, stricter. She pul some papers out of her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Test results for the Virgil translation. We will start from the bottom...Patricia. Jenny puffs out her cheeks. She's not last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absent. Margaret. 48%. Jenny... Jenny winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52%. That would just about scrape a pass in the exam proper. Not good enough for Oxford candidates.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny and her mother are sitting on the sofa, staring int space, clearly upset. On the coffee table in front of the is the test, covered in red ink. They hear a key in the lock, and they look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to him. Jack enters, back from work. He's wearing a suit and carrying a battered briefcase. He looks at them, and then notices the essay on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her Latin, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The test didn't...Well, it didn't go as well as we'd hoped. He picks up the paper.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And you still say I shouldn't go down there and have it out with whatsername? The Latin teacher? Because this is hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: How are you going to "have it out" with her? What are you going to do? Shout at her until she decides I'm much cleverer than she thinks?

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Everyone's doing their best, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What if their best isn't good enough, though, eh? What do we do then?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: We don't go to Oxford. Any of us. Not even you, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Perhaps it's all a waste of time and money anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: You don't mean that.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well, what's she going to do with an English degree? And if she's going to spend three years playing that bloody cello and talking in French to beatniks, then I'm throwing good money after bad. I suppose she might meet a nice lawyer. But she could do that at a dinner dance tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. That's the whole point of an Oxford education. It's the expensive alternative to a dinner dance.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: What about private tuition?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Is anyone listening to me? How much is that going to cost me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five shillings an hour. Maybe a little more for A-level. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five bob! But... we could spend five bob on this and five bob on that, and before we know it that's our savings down the drain. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what else are we spending five bob on? What else are we spending sixpence on? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing. (He gestures round the room.) It's all free. That vase was free. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was, actually. It was a present from Auntie Vi. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That chair was free. The sofa. We don't have to pay for anything. And even if we did, we don't have to work for it. That's the beauty of life, Jenny. Everything's free. Grows on trees. Wonderful, isn't it? (He warms to his theme, and grows progressively more berserk.) We've got a lovely Oxford tree in the garden, lucky for you, so that's Oxford taken care of. And a whole orchard of school trees, so that's all free. I'm sure there are some private tuition trees out there. I'll go and have a look. He stands up. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack... JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, won't take me a minute. I think I saw some at the back there, right next to the pocket money tree. I'll just nip out and check, see that they're doing all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't want anyone climbing over the wall and scrumping, do we? And you never know. Maybe there'll be a man with deep pockets growing out there. Because God knows we need to find you one. He leaves the room, apparently to   look in   the garden the mythical trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny and her mother move to the window to    watch him talking theatrically to the trees. 32    EXT. STREET/COFFEE BAR. DAY. Jenny, Hattie and Tina are walking back from school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could always go to secretarial college with Hattie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Hattie and Tina follow Jenny's eyes, and they see Graham coming towards them pushing his bike, red-faced, trousers tucked into socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Graham. Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you for ages....It all went wrong, didn't it? The tea-party, I mean. Was it because of the year off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. It's just...I've got so much to do if I'm going to get the grades I need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She's got no time for boys. Hattie and Tina try to suppress giggles. Graham turns an even brighter shade of red. Hattie and Tina enter the coffee bar. Jenny feels sorry for him, is on the verge of inviting him to join them...And changes her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Graham.                                             She follows the girls inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S BEDROOM/UPPER HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny is deep in her schoolwork. She has a Latin vocabula propped open on the window-ledge. She looks at it, walks away, mutters to herself, attempting to memorize. Her concentration is broken by a sudden gale of laughter from downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HALL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: She stands outside the living room for a moment, listenin She hears a man's voice that does not belong to her fathe and then more laughter from her father and mother.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: David is in the middle of demonstrating his ability to mimic all of the Goons. Jack and Marjorie are laughing so hard that they can hardly see - they certainly miss Jenny entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Hello. David does the most brilliant Bluebottle, Jenny. Actually, he can do all the                              Goons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I'm very good at                           Eccles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, you've got him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently)                                  But what's he doing here? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't going to disturb you. I knew you'd have your nose to the grindstone. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) You came to see Mum and Dad? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so hard to imagine? Jenny spies an open bottle of wine on the coffee-table. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're drinking? But it's not Christmas! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hark at her! Makes us sound as though we've signed the pledge. You don't know everything about us, you know. We had a life before you came along. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's true. I'm only going on what I've seen over the last sixteen years. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to think what you missed. Nothing much comes to mind. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't stand to see me enjoying myself. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway. Would you excuse me? I've got a huge pile of Latin translation to do. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me David went to Oxford. Jenny looks at David, who stares back at her straight- faced. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: For all the good it did me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What did you read?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, English. Just like every other semi-employed layabout in London.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (marvelling at the coincidence) English! Which college?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Merton.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Isn't that funny?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I was just telling Jack that I'm going back next weekend. I go and see my old professor every now and again.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That's what you need, Jenny. Someone on the inside track. It's not always what you know, is it, David?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Too true. And Clive would love Jenny. Have you ever come across Clive Lewis?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Dad has never come across anyone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I just thought he might know some of the books.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Dad has never read any books.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (stung) What's he written?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wrote a children's book called `The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe' that did very well, I believe. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CS Lewis? That's the Clive you're talking about? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, to us he was just the old codger who taught Medieval literature. But I came to know him very well. We just...got along, do you know what I mean? Everyone murmurs their comprehension. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny used to love those books. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh. That dates me. He was writing them when I was there. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to meet him. There is a pause. Jack and Marjorie look at the floor. Somehow, David has manoeuvred a situation where, effectively, he is the one being asked. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm being slow on the uptake. Would Jenny like to come with me at the weekend? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know about this weekend. But one day, yes, thank you. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How often do you see him? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, once every couple of years. But next time, eh? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Hopefully I'll be there by then. So that won't be much use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose...Would she have to stay the night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I wouldn't want to drive back after one of those Oxford dinners. Jack chuckles knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clive will get her a room in college. That's easy enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like too good an opportunity to pass up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Daddy. It would be so helpful to know something about the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it be a bother to you, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be delighted. Jack, Marjorie and Jenny all beam.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny opens the door for David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was scandalous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. You owe me half-a- crown. He kisses her on the cheek and disappears into the night.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DANNY'S FLAT. DAY
dialogues.text: David and Danny are waiting for the girls to get ready. Danny is sitting sprawled in an armchair; David is pacing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: INT. HELEN'S BEDROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: An ornate four-poster bed occupies most of the space in t room. Helen is doing something to Jenny, but we can't see what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can they only be nearly ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be surprised if three of them come out, you know. That's the only explanation. They're making themselves a friend. LADIES! Let's go. Please.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HELEN'S BEDROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny is wearing a floaty print dress that she has borrow from Helen, and there are lots of other beautiful clothes strewn about the place. Jenny is sitting at the dressing table, being made up by Helen. Jenny looks three or four years older, more sophisticated....more like Helen. She can't believe it. She looks in the mirror, and for a moment, she forgets to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. You'll do. You can keep it. I can only wear so many every day. Jenny emerges from her reverie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrilled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about tonight? Will you be needing a nightie? Or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nightie? Jenny suddenly understands what Helen means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will we be sharing bedrooms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not sleeping with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm...No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Do     you think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're only sixteen. And you don't want to get into the family way, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd make sure that didn't happen. I'm going to do it when I'm seventeen. On my seventeenth birthday, hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With   David? Jenny pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...Golly. I suppose it will be with David, won't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's your birthday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he'll be around in April. If                         that's what you want. Anyway. I'll find you a nightie. Jenny stares at herself in the mirror again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DANNY'S FLAT. DAY
dialogues.text: The girls emerge. Both men are entranced by Jenny's transformation. David can't take his eyes off her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall, we, ah... Make a move?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets to his feet. 42   INT/EXT. CAR COUNTRY ROAD. DAY. The Bristol on the country road to Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR OXFORD DAY
dialogues.text: The Bristol drives through Oxford. Jenny catches a quick glimpse of a dreaming spire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine spending three years here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. She shudders, as if someone has walked over her grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe later. There are a couple of things we have to do. 44   INT/EXT. CAR OXFORD BACK STREET. DAY. Jenny and Helen in the back seat of the car, which is parked outside a house in the back streets of Oxford. There's no sign of Danny and David. Jenny sighs impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's always like this. There are millions of places I've never seen because I've been stuck in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never get out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's never anywhere to go in the places they stop. Jenny looks out of the window. This is self-evidently tru 45   INT. PUB. EVENING. Helen and Danny, Jenny and David are standing in a quiet, old-fashioned pub, warming themselves at an open fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David has a pen in his hand, and he's holding a book - `T Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe'. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Now.Is he Clive, do you think? Or CS? HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm confused now. I thought you'd made him up? DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (attempting, briefly, to be patient) No, we...Never mind. David walks over to the nearest table and writes in the book. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. He stands up, hands the book to Jenny. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads) "To dear Jenny. With the pleasure of meeting you. Come and see me again soon. Clive." HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dirty old man. Laughter. He takes a long drink from his pint of bitter. group of students enter, all carrying musical instruments They stand at the bar, waiting to be served. Jenny stares at them with longing - she wants to be one of them. Helen meanwhile, stares at them as if they were aliens. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) Why are university girls so strange-looking? Helen's right. The girls in the group are all bespectacle and frumpy. The others laugh. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. And they can't all have started off that way, can they? Most girls aren't ugly, but most girl students are. So there must be something about those places that, you know, makes you fat, or spotty, or short-sighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you look at it that way...I mean, that's proper scientific analysis. And you can't argue with science. Helen looks pleased. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still not quite clear on what you want to do when you get here. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to read English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry? HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to read English books? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes. Reading English is just another way of saying... DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't worry, Jenny. You're wasting your breath. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, tomorrow we'll try to get more of a feel for the place. DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. This would be a good place to do a little business. David catches Jenny's eye. This isn't what he meant by "getting a feel for the place." DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All those little old ladies wandering around...I'll bet this place is rife with stats. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please explain what stats are. You're always going on about them. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Think of a number. Now                  think about the most boring                        lesson you've ever had at school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now double it. Done? Doubled? Now                       multiply it by the number you                           first thought of, and there you                         are. That's the official boredom                        content of stats.                                       Jenny laughs. 46   INT. B & B BEDROOM. NIGHT A rather grotty and certainly unromantic B&B bedroom unromantic, in fact, that it even has the same fusty curtains from Jenny's sitting room. David is in bed, his hands behind his head, waiting for Jenny. As far as we ca tell - he's wrapped up in the sheets quite tightly - he's in his underwear. The bedroom is lit unromantically by th 40-watt overhead light. Jenny comes into the room wearing one of Helen's nightdresses, a glamorous satiny item quit inappropriate for the occasion or the surroundings. She looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got exactly the same curtains at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not talk about curtains. You look beautiful. You really are a princess. Jenny was about to get into bed, but his tone makes her pause at the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something you should know, David. I'm...Well, I'm a virgin. And I want to stay that way until I'm seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's good. I think that's right. And for your seventeenth birthday I'm going to take you to Paris or Rome or Florence and make you feel like the most beautiful princess in the kingdom of love. But we can still be romantic, can't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes. Of course we can. If it doesn't mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minnie....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You're my Minnie Mouse, and I'm your bubbalub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. If that's what..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (prompting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bubbalub...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Yes, bubbalub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind if I had a look at what might one day be mine? Just a peek? His eyes stray to her breasts. Jenny stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just want to see them?
