dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to see them. Jenny, flustered and nervous, looks at her nightgown - sh doesn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it fall from your shoulders. She does so. He stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He sits up, and lovingly lifts the straps back up. He smiles at her. Relieved, she smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR COTTAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: The Bristol, containing David and Jenny in the front seat and Danny and Helen in the back, passing through a pretty Oxfordshire village. It pulls up outside a country cottag with a `FOR SALE' sign outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might be worth a look.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAR COTTAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: The four get out of the car, and Jenny follows David and Danny to the front door of the house. Helen hangs back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny...                                                 Jenny turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen will look after you. Go and                        find a nice cup of tea somewhere.                        Jenny is mystified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need looking after, thank                        you very much. David, I want to                          see...                                                   David ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to tell you a                              second time. Now. Run along.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BENCH. DAY
dialogues.text: Helen and Jenny waiting for the boys. Helen is blithe, chatty; Jenny has a face like thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't be long. Either way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Either way"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes they find something, sometimes they don't. In the distance, David is waving at them urgently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when they do find something, we usually have to leave quite quickly. They can be a bit naughty, sometimes. Anyway. It's nice to have company. I'm usually outside on my own. Jenny stares at Helen. She's beginning to realise who she is dealing with.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR NEW COUNTRY ROAD. DAY
dialogues.text: An old picture of   some kind is wedged between Helen and Jenny on the back   seat. Jenny, furious, is staring out the window. Helen   attempts to peer around the partition but settles for a   wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coo-ee. Jenny. Jenny doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about being a little brisk back there, Jenny. We have our way of doing things. Silly, really. Still no response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Jenny. Let's not spoil things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disbelieving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? I'm spoiling things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think there must be some kind of misunderstanding. Jenny shakes her head bitterly. They continue driving in silence.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DANNY'S FLAT. DAY
dialogues.text: The Bristol pulls up outside Danny's Bedford Square flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants to come up   for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. You go. I'll find my own way home. Jenny gets out of the car and starts up the road. David gets out and starts to chase after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny! He catches up with her in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an old map. A Speed. It was cooped up in that miserable little cottage, and she didn't even know what it was. What a waste! It shouldn't spend its life on a wall in wherever the hell we are. It should be with us. We know how to look after it properly. We liberated it. Jenny snorts derisively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liberated! That's one word for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly and passionately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't be bourgeois, Jenny. You're better than that. I know you have fun with us. I can see it. You drink everything I put in front of you down in one, every last drop, and then you slam your glass down on the bar and ask for more, and it's wonderful. We're not clever like you, so we have to be clever in other ways, because if we weren't, there would be no fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to be clever with maps, and..and.. You want to know what stats are? Stats are old ladies who are scared of coloured people. So I move the coloureds in and the old ladies move out and I buy their flats cheap. That's what I do. So now you know. Jenny nods reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you don't like it, then I will understand, and you can go back to Twickenham and listen to                        the Home Service and do your Latin homework. But these weekends, and the restaurants and the concerts..They don't grow on trees. Jenny looks at him, startled. Trees again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand? Of course you do. This is who we are, Jenny. He turns to face her and holds out his hand. On Jenny: is she in or out? Jenny takes his hand. David pulls her towards him, holds her around the waist and begins to dan with her. Further up the pavement, Helen and Danny watch, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. CAR JENNY' HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: David pulls up in the Bristol outside Jenny's house, and they sit in the dark for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you have homework to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh. Yes. Loads. (Beat) Thank you. I had a nice time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised, despite his speech earlier)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? In spite of the, the incident? With the map?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you said in the car, it was a misunderstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. A muddle. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no idea how boring everything was before I met you. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that there's something more than excitement to our relationship. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excitement's a lot, when you're at school and you live in Twickenham. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm trying to say. I want you to like me for who I am, not just what I can do for you. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that is who you are. I've never met anyone like you. Action is character, our English teacher says. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it means that if we never did anything, we wouldn't be anybody. And I never did anything before I met you. And sometimes I think no-one's ever done anything in this stupid country, apart from you. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good place to end the weekend. I'll give you a tinkle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. They look at each other. David is clearly smitten. He mov towards her. He wants to kiss her, but he doesn't want to frighten her - in the end, Jenny makes it easy for him an moves towards him. They kiss gently and tenderly. Flustered, Jenny breaks it off, gets out of the car and goes inside while David watches.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny enters the sitting room with her overnight bag to find the radio on, her father reading the paper and her mother knitting. When Jenny comes in, Jack beams. He has clearly turned some kind of corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here she is! The wanderer returns!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have a nice time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he nice to you? Jenny unzips her bag and pulls out her copy of the book. She hands it to her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look inside. Jack examines the inscription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I never. Look at this, Marjorie. He hands it to her. She examines it reverently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Clive"...Lucky girl. What was he                       like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was just...normal. Kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did he show you round?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he was busy. David did, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it make you want to work harder? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never a dull moment with David, is there? If it's not concerts, it's famous authors. Bit different from that lad you brought home for tea, isn't he? MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David's a lot older than Graham. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham could live to be two hundred, and he still wouldn't be swanning around with famous authors. Hasn't got it in him. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He might become a famous author, for all you know. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being one isn't the same as knowing one, is it? Anyone can be one. But if you move in those circles... JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it says something about you, doesn't it? It says you're going places. It says you're well connected. He's an impressive young man, that David. I like him more and more. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they say opposites attract, don't they? I wouldn't have thought he was your sort. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't. And now he is. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that how you feel, Jenny? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel....I Feel I should do my homework. She leaves the room. Marjorie watches her go thoughtfully

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARK. DAY
dialogues.text: A group of girls cross-country running. Jenny and her friends are at the back of the group, and the gym teacher jogging backwards, gesticulates at them to get a move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies, please. Christmas is                             coming.                                                  They put on enough of a spurt to satisfy her, and then immediately stop when the teacher is no longer watching. Seeing an attractive bench, they sit down. From somewhere under a skirt, Jenny produces a packet of exotic-looking cigarettes and offers them around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russian Sobranies. Hattie and Tina make snooty faces. Jenny takes a cigarett The others follow suit. Jenny lights them, and they all grimace. The contrast between the sophisticated cigarette and the unsophisticated smokers and context is pronounced

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did they come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She might have bought them from the Savoy, or Claridges, or the opera, or some fancy nightclub. Who knows, with Jenny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris. You can't buy them here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly looking at her suspiciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never bought them yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking Tina's grammar cruelly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, you stuck-up cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'll bring you some back, if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Non. HATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's taking you to Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling smugly) Oui.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This term?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peut-etre. TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it your birthday next Tuesday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might be. The two friends shriek and jump up and down. HATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! Your birthday! TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't like to be you. All those dinners you've had off him. Ouch. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have such a Victorian attitude to sex, you two. TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry, Dr Kinsey. We're not all as experienced as you. I mean, you've done it...(She counts on her fingers) I make it never! Can that be right? HATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your parents are just going to let you swan off like that? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't know yet. David's got a plan, he says. He usually has something up his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've noticed that. What did he tell them when you had your weekend in Oxford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (animated by the memory)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it was....(She changes her mind) David went to Oxford. Merton. English. And he offered to show me round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you have a good-looking boyfriend with pots of money, brains and a nice car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently I do. Tina makes a bitter face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they tell us there's a God. Laughter. Jenny glances off into the distance, and spots portly middle-aged woman heading in their direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sod. Miss Davies. They stand up, grind their Sobranies into the mud, kick them under the bench, and set off at a brisk trot. The Sobranie stubs come to rest near a pile of dog poo.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Breakfast on Jenny's birthday. Jenny is at the table buttering toast. Jack is reading the paper, Marjorie is cooking him eggs and bacon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is David taking you somewhere special tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I know of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've asked Graham round for tea and birthday cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we want him round for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I happened to be talking to his mother about something, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you happen to be talking to her about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if David turns up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we expecting David to turn up? Jenny shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might not be a bad thing if he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you think about it, there's more than one way of skinning a cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who's the skinned cat, in                          this enchanting image? Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an education to pursue.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. EVENING
dialogues.text: Graham, Jenny and her father are at the dinner table, sitting in the dark. Marjorie kicks the door open with he foot and comes in holding a birthday cake with seventeen candles burning on it. She puts it down carefully on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blow them out, then, before the whole place burns down. Jenny closes her eyes, makes her wish, blows out her candles. Her father and mother both look at her, apparent attempting to read her mind. Jack gets up to turn the lights on. We can see that by Jenny's side are two unopened, carefully-wrapped presents, both exactly the sa size - clearly books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd like a piece? In truth, the cake is a rather sorry and unappetising specimen. There isn't enough icing on the top. She cuts a couple of slices which immediately collapse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. I'll have one of those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Presents. Without any real enthusiasm, Jenny opens the first one of the two, from her mum and dad. It's a Latin dictionary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you. I    needed a new one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crestfallen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear.                                                  The doorbell rings. Jenny perks up. Jack goes to answer i and immediately the house is energised: it's David.

dialogues.speaker: 58A INT/EXT JENNY'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Jack answers the door to David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good grief. You won't believe this, Jenny. Did you leave anything in the shop? David enters. You can hardly see him for all the parcels and flowers he's carrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a special day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Jenny exchange a glance. Jack comes in behind him. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a special girl. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know it. (to Graham) Hello, young man. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Graham. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham, a pleasure. I'm David. They shake hands. Graham suddenly looks five years younge JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes your dictionary look a bit feeble, eh Graham? Graham looks pained. Marjorie notices. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ours too, come to that. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're not the ones trying to impress her. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, what can I get you to drink? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's everybody else having? What have you got there, Graham? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've given him a glass of pop. GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stung) I'd better be going I have a stack of homework to do. Graham says his goodbyes. He tries to catch Jenny's eye, but she looks away. Marjorie shows him to the door. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Well. You can put the pop away now. What is there for the grown-ups?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glass of something warming? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me so well. Hearty laughter from the two men. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I open anything yet? Marjorie comes back into the room. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for me. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you start on that little lot , I have a surprise. Next weekend, we're all going to Chez Georges to celebrate Jenny's birthday. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) Lovely. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chez Georges is in the Boulevard St Germain. In Paris. Jenny giggles her delight. Jack's smile is a little more forced. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How d'you mean, Paris? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the one, Dad. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panic rising) But..We haven't got any French money. And I'm not sure...I just don't think it would agree with me. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't like us, the French, you know. John Sutton at work went once. They were very rude to him. I'm not sure I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny understands David's ploy perfectly, and the role sh must play. Her eyes fill with tears. Jack notices. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to spoil anyone's fun, but...It's not for me, Europe. We'll go another time. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) You've just said you don't like Europe. What's going to change? It'll have to be Europe, won't it? Because it isn't going to be you. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take her. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely indignant) To France? And leave me here on my own? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for God's sake. Jack looks cornered. He needs to find a way out. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm really sorry to have caused all this to-do. I just thought it might be nice. But I'll go with Aunt Helen and Uncle Daniel. They can have your tickets. Jack looks at him. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Helen? The one who went to                      the concert with you?                                DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's the one. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Well, there we are. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (perplexed) Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Helen! Don't you see? If Aunt Helen's going to be there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the penny apparently dropping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to put a spoke in anyone's wheels. But if you look at it from my angle...A bachelor,                         taking my daughter off to Paris...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, impossible. I hadn't thought it through properly. I do apologise, Jack. Would you prefer it if Helen took Jenny on her own? I don't mind. I've been to Paris before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I couldn't possibly ask...No, no. If Aunt Helen's going... He smiles broadly. He's off the hook. Jenny catches David eye and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Hattie, Tina and Jenny are sitting on their desks, waitin for a lesson to start. Hattie shows Jenny a piece of pape which apparently contains some kind of shopping list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some things you must buy for us, and some things you only have to buy for us if you're a proper, true friend. (She points at Hattie, then at herself.) Chanel perfume, Chanel perfume. (She repeats the gesture) Chanel lipstick, Chanel lipstick. What have I forgotten?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those funny cigarettes you were smoking. Sobranies. Ten packets each. A very small girl, twelve or thirteen, comes in to the classroom and approaches Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the girl going to Paris? Tina, Hattie and Jenny stare at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well are you or aren't you? Because I'd like some perfume. Miss Stubbs comes into the classroom carrying books and essays. She sees the small girl and shoos her out. She th approaches Jenny and whispers discreetly into her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny, the headmistress would like a word at the end of the lesson. I'm afraid that the legend of Mr Rochester may have travelled further than you intended. Jenny looks at her, startled and a little sick. 60   INT. HEADMISTRESS'S OFFICE. DAY. The office is dark, wood-panelled, foreboding, apparently designed to put all visitors ill-at-ease. The headmistres would probably choose to be wood-panelled if she could. She's tweedy, bespectacled, severe. There is a knock at t door. She doesn't look up from her paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come. Jenny enters, looking young and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Miss Mellor. Jenny tries to look back at her with all the courage she can muster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all very excited about your forthcoming trip to Paris. Our excitement, indeed, knows no bounds. Some of us can talk of little else. Jenny looks at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An older man, I understand. A word of warning, Miss Mellor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There may well have been the odd sixth-form girl who has lost an important part of herself - perhaps the best part - while under our supervision. These things happen, regrettably. If, however, we are made aware of this loss, then of course the young lady in question would have to continue her studies elsewhere, if she still has any use for `A'-levels. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I go now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Jenny turns round and walks out without saying another word.

dialogues.speaker: 62PT 1
dialogues.text: Through the window of a hotel suite, we see a BEA jet soaring into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: 62PT 2
dialogues.text: David and Jenny aren't on it, though. They are letting themselves into the room. Jenny stares at the featureless sitting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. I pushed the boat out and got us a suite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A suite!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if work stops us getting to Paris until tomorrow, then work can buy us a nice hotel room. Anyway, it's a special occasion, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have thought that tonight of all nights we only need a bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on David's reaction      -   she hasn't forgotten t tonight's the night.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: David and Jenny in bed, in a dimly lit bedroom. They are kissing - David more passionately than Jenny. He is makin little whimpers of excitement, and Jenny is clearly tryin hard to hide her nerves. We're acutely aware of her age, and of her virginity. Suddenly David breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on a second. I've got something. Rather absurdly, he half-disappears over the side of the bed, reaching for something on the floor. He comes back with a banana. Jenny stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What on earth is that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought....I thought we might want to practice. Jenny shrieks with horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a banana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we'd get the messy bit over with first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, I don't want to lose my virginity to a piece of fruit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. David attempts to kiss her again. Jenny wriggles clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's wait until we get to Paris. I think the moment might have gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Minnie. I'm such a fool. Jenny doesn't deny it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And David..... if tomorrow night does happen, it will never happen again, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why won't it ever happen again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the first time can only happen once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, please...No Minnies. No baby- talk. I'm not old enough for baby- talk. Treat me like a grown-up. David looks chastened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Let's go and sit in our                         sitting-room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheered up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooray! I'll order some champagne. Jenny looks at him with what might, from one angle, be construed as fondness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette Greco on the soundtrack. Jenny leans against a wall, the Seine and Notre Dame behind her. David takes he picture. She looks fantastic in the clothes David has giv her for her birthday.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ART GALLERY. DAY
dialogues.text: A crowded Left Bank gallery. Jenny is sitting on the floo watching an impossibly handsome young Frenchman paint bla the body of an impressively passive naked woman. The youn man sitting next to Jenny gives her an appraising look. David, standing at the back and looking square and uncomfortable, notices.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RECORD SHOP. DAY
dialogues.text: We see three listening booths, all containing customers. Jenny and David are in the middle booth, listening to the Juliette Greco song on the soundtrack. (For a moment, the sound quality changes - soundtrack becomes source music, seamlessly.) Jenny is studying the sleeve. She wants to h herself, she's so excited. 67   EXT. CAFE. EVENING. A Left Bank cafe - David and Jenny are eating steak frite outside, drinking vin ordinaire, watching the world go by They are both anticipating the night ahead.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARIS HOTEL. DAWN
dialogues.text: Jenny is smoking at the second-floor window of a simple, pretty Parisian hotel, wearing a glamorous-looking slip a looking at the street life below her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL ROOM. DAWN
dialogues.text: The bedroom is simple and romantic - everything the airpo hotel wasn't. David is lying amid rumpled sheets, smoking what is clearly a post-coital cigarette, and watching Jen from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still feel like a schoolgirl? Jenny turns round, smiles, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it wasn't too uncomfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not after the...first bit. It's funny, though, isn't it? All that poetry, and all those songs and films, about something that lasts no time at all? David looks at her. She isn't being cruel. She just doesn know any different. She returns to her people-watching. H smokes ruminatively.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARK. DAY
dialogues.text: ...Jenny in her games kit, smoking her Sobranie with her friends on the park bench again. Hattie and Tina are examining their bottles of Chanel reverently. Jenny is ba to being her seventeen-year-old self; somehow her sevente year-old self looks comical, and no longer appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you go back to double French when you've had a weekend with an older man in a posh hotel in Paris? You wouldn't catch me coming anywhere near this dump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (artfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't all glamour. We spent half the weekend at Heathrow in a hotel suite .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A suite? Oh my God. Your life. They smoke their Sobranies ruminatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to miss it. All the swanning around in posh hotels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why will I need to miss it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you go to Oxford. Unless you're planning on being with David forever. Jenny doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Won't you miss it? Jenny shrugs. Clearly she will, and clearly she hasn't thought about it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll miss it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny laughs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny's English class file past Miss Stubbs at the end of lesson. Miss Stubbs stops Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny, could I have a word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.(To Hattie and Tina) I'll catch you up. Miss Stubbs waits until the room empties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can do anything you want, Jenny. You know that. You're clever and you're pretty... But sometimes those things fight. I'm worried that at the moment clever Jenny and pretty Jenny are fighting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't bear it if clever Jenny lost. It's because of people like you that I plough through illiterate essays by Sandra Lovell about her pony. And there aren't many of you, I can tell you. One every few years. Is your boyfriend interested in clever Jenny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interested enough to let her do what she wants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He couldn't stop me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He might not have to stop you. That's what I'm trying to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) I'm not sure what you're trying to tell me. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you to go to Oxford. No matter what. Or you'll break my heart. Jenny looks at her. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Where did you go? MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder, bolder) Where did you go? Which university? MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girton. Cambridge. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean? `Oh'? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're clever. And you're pretty. So presumably, Clever Miss Stubbs won. And here you are, reading all those pony essays. I don't know. These last few months, I've been to Paris, and to jazz clubs, and I've eaten in wonderful restaurants, and seen wonderful films, heard beautiful music... MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you have. But I was filled up with beautiful things, books and music and conversation, in exactly the same way at Cambridge. And I didn't have to pay the same sort of price. Are you taking precautions, Jenny? Jenny stares at her angrily. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing to do with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe our lives are always going to end up with pony essays. Or housework. And yes, maybe we'll go up to Oxford. But if we're all going to die the moment we graduate, maybe it's what we do before that counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you think I'm dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you're dead. But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better get to your next class. She turns her back on Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Helen, Danny, Jenny get out of David's Bristol, which is parked outside a nightclub called Esmerelda's Barn. David has parked next to a white Rolls-Royce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the Rolls- Royce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we know the person who owns this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Perec Rachman. He's a....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bastard. Danny and David laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a business acquaintance, and we need to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gathered that much. But why do we have to crawl around the West End looking for his car? Why don't you just make an appointment, if you want to see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men snigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Ring his office? Talk to his secretary? That isn't how it works with him, dear.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLUB. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The four walk in and take their coats over to the cloakroom. The club is a smoky West End club, full of smartly-dressed and dubious-looking men, and young, glamorous, dubious-looking women. Jenny and Helen look ou of place - Helen too ethereal, Jenny too innocent. There jazz playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is. We see a nasty-looking man in his late 30s/early 40s. He wearing a white sharksin suit and smoking a big cigar. He standing by the roulette table, talking to an even nastie looking man in a dark suit. They find a table at the back and sit down. A waitress comes over to their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bottle of champagne, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh-ho. Champagne, eh? He looks at Jenny and David expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be bashful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Be Sneezy. Everyone ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then. If you won't tell them I will. Jenny got two As and a B in her mock-A levels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The B was in Latin. But it's much better than it was, isn't it, Minnie? Rachman is now standing on his own. Danny nudges David, a they go over to talk to him just as the champagne arrives The waiter pops the bottle of champagne and pours two glasses. The girls smile and clink glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone told me that in fifty years no-one will speak Latin, probably. Not even Latin people. So you shouldn't mind too much about your B. Jenny stares at her, trying to think of a response.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLUB. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Danny and David are at the bar, having just finished talking to Rachman. Danny puffs out his cheeks and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not sure you'd want him                        to marry your sister. I'm not                            even sure you'd want to talk to                          him in a night-club, come to                             that.                                                    They both chuckle. There is a silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do know what you're doing, old chap? With Jenny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the one, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've heard that before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can see she's different. She's got everything. You've got Helen, and....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you've got Helen with brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rumbled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to see her hurt. They make their way back to their table.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLUB. NIGHT
dialogues.text: While David and Helen watch, Danny and Jenny dance. Danny a good dancer; Jenny is nervous at first, but becomes mor comfortable and more expressive, with Danny's help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowing that she should make conversation, as all the couples around her are doing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you...Have you bought any more paintings recently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I? Let's think? Oh, I picked up a little Piper the other day. A good `un, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still trying to work out what makes good things good. It's hard, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is, Jenny, you know, without necessarily being able to explain why. You've got taste. That's not even half the battle. That's the whole war. Jenny smiles at him with gratitude. There is a sudden closeness between them. David is watching them carefully. They return to their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny, we should go. It's late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alas. One day, school will be over forever, and we can talk about art all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Danny)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all right in a taxi, aren't you? He guides Jenny firmly out of the club. 77   EXT. CLUB. NIGHT. Jenny is about to to open the passenger door of the Bristol, but David stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait there. He runs to the back of the car, opens the boot and starts rummaging through it. It seems to be full of everything but the thing he's looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? He slams the boot shut and comes back empty-handed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you marry me? Jenny stares at him for a moment, then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I had a ring. It wouldn't have been the right one. But it would have done for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes twinkling with amusement)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helplessly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please take me home. She gets into the car. We see the desperation in David's face, lit by the headlights of a passing taxi, as he slam the door on Jenny after she's got in.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SCHOOL YARD. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny, Tina and Hattie all smoking in the school toilets. Jenny is distracted, and standing apart from the others. Tina looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you say `A penny for your thoughts?' in French?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A franc is too much, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For her thoughts, yes. You'd be overpaying by about ninety-nine centimes. Suddenly the door bursts open and the Latin teacher comes in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HEAD'S OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: The three girls are lined up in front of the headmistress hands by their sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised that you two are standing in front of me. I'm not surprised to find you here, Miss Mellor, though I do feel rather like the judge who sent Al Capone to prison for tax evasion. We take a very dim view of smoking. We take an even dimmer view of some of your other behaviour, which as far as we know has taken place off school premises. Your appearance here today, however, allows me to remind you that we are trying to teach you how to become young ladies, not nightclub hostesses. In reality, of course, you are neither. You are merely silly little girls. Detention after school. Go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny's face sets hard. Something in her shuts down.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JENNY'S BALCONY. EVENING
dialogues.text: Jenny is smoking on the balcony. 80A   INT. JENNY'S BEDROOM. Jenny is at her desk in her bedroom, trying to work, but she can't concentrate. Her hair is tied back in a pony- tail. She gets up, pulls back the curtains, looks out of the window. We see what she sees: a sleepy suburban stree at night. She looks back at her desk. It looks even more boring than the street. She looks at her scrubbed sevente year-old face in the mirror - so much younger than the Jenny we have seen with David. She makes herself up, and she gets older and more glamorous before our eyes. In her make-up and her school uniform, she's half-woman, half- child. We hear the noises drifting up from the kitchen: t radio, the washing-up, occasional muffled conversation. Jenny walks out of the bedroom and slips downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. EVENING
dialogues.text: Jenny's mother and father are doing the washing up and listening to the radio. They have their backs to the door Jenny enters the room quietly and watches them for a mome

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do need some looking after, but nothing that will require too much work. Just leave them in your potting shed for a couple of weeks, and they'll look after themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, aye. The potting shed. Who does he think I am? Prince Rainier of Monaco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I got married instead of going to college? Jack and Marjorie turn around and stare at this strange apparition wearing too much make-up and a school uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would depend who it was, surely? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it? That's interesting. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course it would. I wouldn't want you married off just for the sake of it. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has somebody asked you? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Marjorie rolls her eyes. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you tell him? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing yet. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. A man I just met walking his dog. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David's asked you to marry him? Bloody hell. Pardon my French. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any choice? Or is it too late. She looks at her daughter knowingly. Jack merely looks confused. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she's got a choice. But it's an interesting one, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where you're supposed to say, "But what about Oxford?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Looked at it one way, you wouldn't really need to go now, would you? He's a man going places. And say what you like, but they know how to take care of their money, don't they? He'll see you're looked after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, turning the words over in her mouth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't need to go. Would you like to expand on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. Jenny laughs bitterly. She can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that Latin! All those essays! What was the point? Why didn't you just send me out prowling round nightclubs? It would have been less trouble. And I might have had more fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know about nightclubs. We knew about education. Anyway, it all turned out for the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't have wanted you if you were thick, would he? Jenny stares at them and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: English. Miss Stubbs is standing at the front   of the cl holding a copy of King Lear, and listening as   various members of the class massacre the text. Some    are messi about by overacting; others read to the best     of their ability, tonelessly and with no understanding   of the wo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lear himself is being read by Ann, the bespectacled girl from the first scene. She's no King Lear, and she's one o the bad readers. GIRL 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May not an ass know when the cart draws the horse? Sings whoop jug I love thee. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, when it says `Sings', it means he sings those words. Girl 1 looks at her blankly. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. Lear... ANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does any here know me. This is not Lear. Does Lear walk thus? TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce, to Jenny, in the seat next to her) No. Jenny starts to giggle. ANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak thus? Tina shakes her head. ANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are his eyes? Tina doesn't need to say anything - she just looks at Jenny, makes a pair of spectacles with her fingers and squints. Jenny's giggling fit increases in intensity. ANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either his notion weakens, or his discernings are lethargied. Ha! Waking? Tis not so. Who is it that can tell me who I am? Jenny's arm shoots up, as if to answer the question. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh. Miss. Me. I can. Miss Stubbs looks at Jenny more in sorrow than in anger - Jenny's behaviour now is something new in their relationship. Jenny stares back at her defiantly. Suddenl Miss Stubbs notices something glinting on her hand: an engagement ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jenny. She is, as she promised she would be, heartbroken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it off. Hattie, who is sitting behind Jenny, notices the ring, to for the first time. HATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Is that really what I think it is? I'M GOING TO BE A

dialogues.speaker: BRIDESMAID
dialogues.text: There is an excited susurration in the classroom. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know there's a school rule about jewelry. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the girls in this room are wearing jewelry. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But none of it is going to ruin their lives. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) We have a difference of opinion on that. Miss Stubbs stares at her. Jenny can only just steel herself to stare back. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see who's right. Come with me. Jenny doesn't move. MISS STUBBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't make me drag you out like a child. Jenny gets to her feet. Teacher and pupil leave the room, while the rest of the class watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far advanced are these ridiculous plans? Have you set a date? Have you decided on a church?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't be getting married in a church. David's Jewish. The headmistress stares at her, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewish? He's a Jew? You're aware, I take it, that the Jews killed our Lord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to feel less intimidated by her surroundings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're aware, I suppose, that our Lord was Jewish? The headmistress snorts scornfully

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose he told you that. We're all very sorry about what happened in the War. But there's no excuse for that sort of malicious and untruthful propaganda. Jenny smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I can now see that you are even more in need of responsible advice than I realised. Is it true that you don't intend to sit for your exams? And therefore you won't be applying for University?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody has been able to explain to me the point of University.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore I don't see the point of the exams, either. HEADMISTRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody does anything worth doing without a degree. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And nobody does anything worth doing with one, either. No woman, anyway. HEADMISTRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what I do isn't worth doing. Or what Miss Stubbs does, or Mrs Wilson, or any of us here. Jenny doesn't say anything. The headmistress takes her silence as an admission of defeat. HEADMISTRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because none of us would be here without our degrees, you realise that, don't you? And yes, of course studying is hard, and boring, and... Jenny can't contain herself any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boring!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry? JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Studying is hard and boring. Teaching is hard and boring. So you're telling me to be bored, and then bored, and then finally bored again, this time for the rest of my life. This whole stupid country is bored. There's no life in it, or colour in it, or fun in it. It's probably just as well that the Russians are going to drop a nuclear bomb on us any day now. So my choice is either to do something hard and boring, OR to marry my... my Jew, and go to Paris and Rome and listen to jazz and read and eat good food in nice restaurants and have fun. It's not enough to educate us any more, Mrs Walters. You've got to tell us why you're doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because without formal qualifications... She grinds to a halt. She has never had to answer this question before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't have to be teaching, you know. There's the Civil Service. Jenny stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wish to be impertinent, Mrs Walters. But it is an argument worth rehearsing. You never know. Someone else might want to know what the point of it all is, one day. She leaves the office.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny is half-walking, half-running, towards the school gates. She's scared, of course, but exhilarated, too. All that pressure, and all those years of education, suddenly over, unexpectedly, and certainly unceremoniously. She looks neither left nor right, but other girls, younger girls, watch her through the windows as she leaves. Jenny doesn't even look round when she goes through the school gates.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. EVENING
dialogues.text: Later. Jenny and Marjorie are sitting at the kitchen tabl Jack is standing over them; he hasn't even taken his coat off, or put his briefcase down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How d'you mean, left? Jenny doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your exams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sitting them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to tell people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (witheringly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, telling people. I'd forgotten that what we tell people is more important than anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that... Marjorie knows what he's going to say, and doesn't want h to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No need for Jack. She should hear it. All that money! Do you know how much it's cost me for you to go through school and take no exams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure David will pay you back. Send him a bill. As you said, he wouldn't have wanted me if I was dim, so he should fork out. Just tell me why there's a point in sitting my exams, and there's no point in me going to University. Jack gapes at her. He's floundering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what your trouble is, don't you? You're too clever by half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In which case I should have left school years ago, shouldn't I? Ask them for the money back. If I'm too clever by half, you overpaid by a third.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DANNY'S FLAT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Danny, Helen, David and Jenny are in Danny's flat; we hav just missed The Announcement - there is champagne already open. Danny glances quickly and discreetly at David, who catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's...Gosh. That's fantastic news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny isn't so pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cool)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. There is much chinking of glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd see sense about university. Jenny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll stay pretty now. Laughter from David and Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I still allowed to read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English? Books? More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't be laughing when she goes all speccy and spotty, David. Helen is bemused by their mirth. Danny watches   David thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DANNY'S. NIGHT
dialogues.text: David and Jenny come out of Danny's flat and approach David's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny didn't seem very pleased about our engagement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that, too! I was wondering whether he might be a bit jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying not to be pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jealous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may have noticed that Helen's not really Oxford material. I'm going to keep him out of your way. They both smile. David opens the door for Jenny and she gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny is making David a cup of tea. Her mother is keeping an eye on Jenny - in Marjorie's mind at least, this is a rehearsal for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't put my...my stamp on it                         yet. Haven't had time. It needs a                         woman's touch, really. And if you                         don't like it, we can move. Just                          say the word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the flat again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to put the cosy on                               straight away.                                            Jenny sighs and rolls her eyes. She picks up the hand- knitted tea-cosy and puts it on her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like that?                                                David laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oblivious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. On the tea-pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.                                                       She puts the tea-cosy on the tea-pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just down from Russell Square.                            Two minutes' walk from the                                underground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny! We could walk to...(She              tries to think of somewhere Jenny           might find interesting.) We could           walk to the British Museum!                 Jenny gives her a look.                               MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll leave you to it. Don't let             it stew.                                    She leaves the room.                                  JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is where you're living?            DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've stayed there for the last              couple of nights. (Beat) On and             off.                                        JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've stayed there two nights              "on and off"?                               DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that tea ready? One sugar,               please.                                     JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated by his                      evasions)                              David!                                      DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. You must think I'm               very odd.                                   JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but.... You seem to float               around. I never know where you              are.                                        She hands him his tea.                                DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wandering Jew.(He pauses to               take a sip.) If I tell you                  something, will you promise not             to laugh?                                   JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends on how funny it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all live at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I mean...I live at home...in                          the same way that you live at                             home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I live with my mother and                             fa...(It clicks.) You don't mean                          it.                                                       David nods, shamefacedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother and father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just my mother. My father's dead.                         I've been meaning to tell you,                            Minnie, and it would have been                            much better than all those silly                          lies. But...                                              He looks quite upset. We warm to him. Jenny leans over an takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway. You can see how much I                            need you. And you won't regret                            this, I promise. We'll have so                            much fun. And just think. When we                         get married, you won't have to                            wait in the car while I do my                             business.. You'll be waiting at                           home, looking at the Burne-Jones                          on the wall. Home, Minnie. Our                            home. Can you imagine?                                    Close on Jenny. She can't imagine, really.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COFFEE BAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny, Tina and Hattie in the coffee bar. Jenny is eagerl scanning the English literature exam paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you do this one? "Show from any TWO scenes in `Pride and Prejudice' how far it is true that Jane Austen's methods are `essentially dramatic'".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says two here. Look. She shows the paper to Hattie. Hattie slumps onto the formica table and groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two. Two. Two. I can't believe it. Tina rubs Hattie's head sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an unfair question. You're hopeless at maths. What do you do all day, anyway, Lady Muck? Jenny shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been looking at flats. I've been to look at dresses. I've been reading a lot, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reading, trying on dresses... Where did we go wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French. The translation paper. Jenny is lapping it all up. She might even be envious.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. EVENING
dialogues.text: Jenny and Marjorie are in the sitting room, all dressed u and waiting for David to come and pick them up. Jenny loo great, as usual; her mother looks smart, if somewhat old- fashioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. He'll find a nice                        place in no time. He sees plenty                      of them.                                              JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure he sees plenty of                        nice places.                                          Would you like a radiogram for a wedding present? We love ours. Something about this depresses Jenny. Marjorie notices. MARJORIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't be bored, you know. He's not boring. Now they are both thoughtful. As if on cue, Jack comes in the sitting room, pulling at his tie, looking apprehensiv He appears to be wearing Brylcreem. He looks like a littl boy who has been made to put on his Sunday best. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of things can you have for starters? I mean, how will I know what are starters and what aren't? I'm all right if it's soup or fruit juice. But if it's anything more than that... JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been through this, Dad. It'll be quite clearly marked on the menu. The doorbell rings. Jack stiffens. Jenny goes to answer t door. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you three go out? I'll be happy here with a tin of... David enters the room. He is relaxed, happy. He has worn tie, possibly because he knew that Jack would wear a tie. Jack and Marjorie stand, and they exchange greetings. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody ready? I think you'll like this place, Jack. Their wine list is as good as anything I've seen in London. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone told me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, probably. Who else would it have been?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET/JENNY'S HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jack and Marjorie approach David's Bristol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping you'd take us in this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you won't want to go in anything else after tonight. Mind you, it drinks petrol. I'm afraid we'll have to stop on the way in to town. He opens the back door for his future in-laws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame. Monsieur. They get in, he closes the door, runs round to open the front passenger door for Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: David starts the car, and glances in the rear-view mirror

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like Eamonn Andrews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a good thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Eamonn Andrews is the poshest person that Jack can imagine being.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET/PETROL STATION. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Bristol cruises down a London arterial road.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: We see, from David's POV, a petrol station approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about this. He slows the car and turns in to the garage.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GARAGE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: David gets out of the car as the attendant comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I help you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might as well fill her up. David looks around and spots a phone box just outside the garage. He leans in through the open car window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just going to make a quick call. I'll be two ticks.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny watches him walk towards the phone box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we should offer him some petrol money? Or would he feel insulted? Jenny watches David as he dials the number. He notices he waves, puts the money in the slot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd feel insulted, probably. He said tonight was his treat. That must include the petrol, for God's sakes? David starts to talk, and turns away, as if he's frighten that someone in the car can lip-read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? Nobody pays him any attention. They lapse into silence. Jack starts to fiddle with the features in the car - a table springs down from the seat in front of him, much to his alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God almighty. What have I done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny opens the glove compartment, looking for the cigarettes that David always keeps there. She finds the cigarettes, and closes the glove compartment. But she has seen something in there, so she opens it again. She takes out some letters and papers and starts to look through them.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GARAGE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: David has finished his phone call and is walking towards the car. He sees Jenny looking through letters and papers sees the open glove compartment, starts to run across the forecourt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny! It's too late. We see Jenny's stricken face, gleaming in someone else's headlights.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: David gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as cold as ice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take us home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's been a...Jenny's had a bit of a shock. Jenny laughs, mirthlessly, then starts to weep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's another one of David's little muddles and misunderstandings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny, it's not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear another word from anybody. Take me home. NOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marjorie and Jack look at each other. David swings the ca around and they drive home in silence; Jenny cries constantly, without making a sound.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JENNY'S HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Bristol draws up outside Jenny's house. David jumps o of the car and lets Marjorie and Jack out. Jack starts to walk towards the house and then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can sort this out, can't you, David? Jenny gets out of the car too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I can. She's just got the wrong end of the stick about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go inside, Dad. Jenny and David watch Jack and Marjorie go into the house The moment the door is closed, Jenny walks towards David. She's holding a bunch of letters that she took out of the glove compartment. She starts to throw them at him, one b one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr and Mrs David Goldman, Mr and                         Mrs David Goldman, Mr and Mrs                            David Goldman, Mr and Mrs David                          Goldman..                                                When she has thrown the last one, she flies at David - sh slaps him, punches him, scratches him. David tries to gra her hands, but she's too wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're MARRIED!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legally, yes, but... Finally he manages to subdue her. She leans against the car, distraught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When were you going to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon. It just - it never seemed the right time. You seemed so happy, and I was happy, and...It would have spoiled everything. What can I do, Minnie? What can I do? How can... JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oh,   Jenny. I'm just too busy to find   somewhere to live...I live with   my mummy." You were living with   your wife! All this time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny... JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your address? David gestures vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Byron Avenue. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Byron Avenue! It's no wonder we kept bumping into each other, then, is it? What number? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no point.. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen. Jenny picks one of the envelopes up off the ground and looks at it. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly sarcastic) Good grief. It's the truth. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. You have to understand. I was with you just about all the spare time I had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spare time? Spare time? I can't tell you how grateful I am. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be like this. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing. I left school. I didn't take my exams. Where's it all gone, now? I gave my life away.                                                 DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny, I can get a divorce. Everything will turn out for   the best. You'll see. We can see Jack and Marjorie peering through the lace curtains anxiously. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go and tell them. Go and tell them, then go and tell your wife. I want to see you. I want to stand there and watch. David stands on the pavement, looking towards the house. looks away; he can't make eye contact with Jenny's parent DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not going to listen to me now. Let me come round tomorrow. When everyone's calmed down a bit. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly desperate) Please don't leave me to tell them on my own. Please. You owe me that much. You owe them that much. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly) I owe them a lot more than that. I owe them everything. They gave me you. He opens the boot. It's full of cases of whiskey. Jenny doesn't even bother asking what they are doing there. Dav takes one of the bottles, opens it, takes a long slug. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes. And then I'll come out and drag you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny marches into the house and slams the door. The came stays on David. He gets back into the car and takes another slug of whiskey. Then his shoulders begin to shake, and he cries and cries.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny comes in, leaving the door open for David. Her parents are standing in the sitting room, looking at her anxiously. Their coats are still on, and they haven't put the lights on yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's helping himself to some Dutch courage before facing you. Stolen Dutch courage, from the look of it. He has something to tell you. She stands, pale and young-looking again, opposite her parents. Suddenly they are all three lit up by headlights Shot from their POV of the Bristol roaring off up the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just drove off. We close slowly in on Jenny's face. But of course he'd drive off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pathetic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell us? Please? Jenny? Jenny can't deal with her own pain, let alone his. He already looks like a broken, foolish old man. They should hug. But they don't.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET/DAVID'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: A suburban street, full of semi-detached houses, not far from Jenny's house. Jenny walks down the road tentatively she's looking at the numbers on the houses. She looks you again - tired, no make-up, no elegant clothes. She can't bring herself to wear anything that David bought her. She hesitates at the top of the driveway to the house, steels herself to walk down. But just at that moment the door opens; there's a homely-looking woman, early 30s. Sh is holding the hand of a three-year-old. Jenny is stunned But there's more to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman deposits the child in the drive, goes back into the house, comes out behind an enormous 1950s pram. David has found time to father another baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Hello. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost inaudible) Hello. I'm sorry. I think I must have the wrong house. The woman stares at her. JENNY
