dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I wanted number...It's my cello lesson. Silly. I... She dries up and looks at the woman helplessly. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Don't tell me. Good God. You're a child. Jenny blushes. Beat. She turns and tries to walk back up the driveway, but the woman won't let her go. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. You stay here. If you're old enough to sleep with him, you're old enough to look at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. But she doesn't move, either. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't know about any of this. Presumably. Jenny shakes her head. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They never do. Did he ask you to marry him? Jenny nods. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course he did. You're not in the family way, are you? Because that's happened before. Jenny shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God for that. At least you can escape intact. (Beat) Relatively speaking. Not all of them have done. She nods at the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why he never goes through with anything. He does love them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking into the pram)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He. (Bitterly) He's four months old. Jenny does the maths. It's all she can do to stop herself from reeling backwards - she's visibly shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four months!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Babies often are that sort of age. Perhaps you can remember a night four months ago when he seemed a little distracted. Anyway. If you'll excuse us. She pushes past Jenny and leaves her standing bereft on t path.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JENNY'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Marjorie and Jack are in the kitchen. Marjorie is sipping tea, shoulders hunched, defeated. Jack is pacing around t room, furious. Normal life has clearly been suspended during this crisis. Jenny walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw her. I didn't talk to her. There wasn't any need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we've got to have this out. If you won't do it, I will. He starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon? I'm still your father, Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're my father again, are you? What were you when you encouraged me to throw my life away? I'm a silly schoolgirl. Was, anyway. Silly schoolgirls are always being seduced by glamorous older men. But what about you two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't... He gives up hopelessly. Marjorie says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now I've got nothing. I'm...I'm broken. Jack looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean....what I think it means, does it? It can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me that you didn't...you haven't, you know...You didn't....                                    Jenny looks at him in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered how stupid you were. Now I know.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jack stands outside Jenny's bedroom door with a cup of te He knocks tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Close-up of the floaty print dress that Helen gave her. T dress is suddenly jerked out of shot, and we pull back to reveal a weeping Jenny stuffing it violently into an already full box of things she is throwing out. The contents represent her now-despised, David-created adult self. We can see Juliette Greco albums, photos, expensive looking jewelry boxes. She continues to stuff things into the box. There's a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny. She continue to put her David-life away into bags. She ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jack is almost in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a cup of tea for you here. No answer. He puts the tea on the floor, and sits down ne to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I made a mess of everything. He waits for an answer - nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All my life I've been scared, and I didn't want you to be scared. That's why I wanted you to go to Oxford. So that if someone asked you out to a nice restaurant, you wouldn't panic about what was a starter and what was a main course. And then David came along, and he had money, and he knew famous writers, and he knew how to get to classical music concerts. But he wasn't who he said he was. He wasn't who you said he was, either.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny is about to rip a poster off the wall, but she pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other day, your mother and I were listening to a programme about CS Lewis on the radio, and they said he moved to Cambridge in 1954. And I said to Marjorie, Well, they've got that wrong, because how would our Jenny get her book signed, if he wasn't in Oxford?

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny's face crumples. She knows he's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DANNY'S FLAT. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny is sitting on the sofa in Danny's flat. Danny and Helen are in dressing gowns; there are newspapers strewn around. Danny pours her a brandy. Helen is sitting next t her, holding her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really understand what                           difference it makes. When I found                        out that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen! Not now.                                          Helen shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to tell him. I'm not                             speaking to him now, if that's                           any consolation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a funny world you people                            live in. You both watched me...                          carrying on with a married man,                          but you don't think it's worth                           saying anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, well if you want that sort of                        conversation...You watched David                         and I help ourselves to a map,                           and you didn't say much, either.                         He holds Jenny's gaze. She looks away.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HEADMISTRESS'S OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny has put on her school uniform for this meeting; it completes a circle. She's back where she started from, or would like to be, anyway. If she seems older than she did when we first met her, it's because things have happened her, and they've left a mark on her face. She's worried a tired. The headmistress, meanwhile, is delighted by her return - but only because of the opportunities for smugne and schadenfreude it provides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Your Jewish friend turned out to be married already, I understand. How unfortunate. Jenny doesn't say anything. She has clearly decided to swallow anything she has to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway. How do you think we can help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to repeat my last year at school. Start all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the impression the last time we spoke that you didn't see the point of school. Or of me, or of any of us here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I was stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what is the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that I need to go to university.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happens if some other chap wants to marry you during your studies next year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other chap? There won't be any other chaps. Not for a long, long time, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I think you're the sort of young lady who attracts chaps whether she wants to or not. No,I think the offer of a place at this school would be wasted on you. You showed how little you valued us only weeks ago. And I must confess that it gives me a sort of grim satisfaction to return the sentiment now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it really so grim, your satisfaction?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gives me no pleasure to see our schoolgirls throw their lives away. Although, of course, you're not one of our schoolgirls any more. Through your own volition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you think I'm a ruined woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're not a woman. Beat. Jenny stands up and leaves without saying a word. T headmistress is pleased with her final line.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jenny working hard in her room. It's been completely stripped bare of everything except schoolbooks. She has become ageless, genderless - her life is now monastic.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARK. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny walking alone through her old park.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COFFEE BAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny on her own, smoking nervously. Hattie and Tina come in. They obviously haven't seen her since it all happened They both hug her sympathetically and sit down. Nobody knows what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure my uncle knows someone who could kill him. If that would help. Jenny smiles wanly, and briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should have stopped you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you want to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we didn't. Why would we stop you? Restaurants, hotels, foreign cities, no exams...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Who'd have thought there'd be a down side to all that? I could tell you all about the imagery in Jane Eyre. But I couldn't see that a man who stole maps from old ladies might be a liar. They look at her. This is new information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you'd told us that we might have tried to stop you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a lot of things I didn't tell you. I was dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the thing about our lives, isn't it? It's so easy to fall asleep, when there's nothing to keep you awake. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you getting on with the work all right on your own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartfelt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, I'm not. 114   EXT. STREET MISS STUBBS FLAT. DUSK. Jenny in a suburban street. She's looking for an address. She finds the house, walks down the path, rings on a bell Miss Stubbs comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny! It's a warm greeting. She ushers her inside. 115   INT. MISS STUBBS' FLAT. DUSK. It's a proper Bohemian flat, up in the eaves. There are books and papers and paintings covering every available surface. Jenny looks around. Finally, for the first time, we see her in somewhere she can feel at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is lovely. Miss Stubbs makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it is. Really. I'd love to live somewhere like this. Miss Stubbs laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's not hard. Go to Oxford and become a teacher and this is what you end up with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all these books and pictures....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penguin paperbacks. Posters and postcards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apparently understanding something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but...That's all you need, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a place to...I'm sorry I said those silly things. I didn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's forget all about it. A poster catches Jenny's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Burne-Jones. Miss Stubbs laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make it sound as though it's an original. Do you like him? Jenny pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I do. Still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still? Gosh, you sound very old and wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartfelt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel old. But really not very wise. Miss Stubbs, I'm....I need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so hoping that's what you were going to say.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET IN OXFORD. DAY
dialogues.text: Eighteen months later. Swelling orchestral music. Close o Jenny cycling, absorbed, happy, the cello strapped to her precariously. The camera pulls back to show her cycling through the streets of Oxford. She's done it. We follow h for a little while. She dismounts outside a church and leans the bike against a wall. Just as she's about to lea it, she sees something and freezes. We follow her gaze: it's the red Bristol, parked a little way down the road just in front of her. She scans the street to see if she can find David. She can - he's coming round a corner, a littler further down the street, unwrapping a packet of cigarettes. Jenny moves into his eye-line. He sees her, stops, then walks towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny. Jenny says nothing. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny. Minnie. I wanted to tell you that I am going to ask my wife for a divorce. Jenny looks at him disbelievingly. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you understand what you've done? David looks at her. This isn't going to be as easy as he thought. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see my behaviour must have been... confusing. But we've never sat down and had a proper chat about it all. About the whys and wherefores. They can wait. The important thing is that you're still my Minnie Mouse, and I love you, and you had fun. You know you had fun. JENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I had fun. But I had fun with the wrong person, at all the                     wrong times. And I can't ever get those times back, now.(Beat)                          Look, David. I'm in Oxford. Every                     day I wake up and pinch myself. And when I think how close I                          came...                                               She looks at him and shakes her head, as if awaking from dream. A young man stops behind her on his bike, dismount leans his bike against the wall next to hers, waits for h to finish. She turns her back on David, and the young man offers her his arm. They walk away together, and David stares longingly after them. THE END
